caseTitle: ASANTE v. NANA YAW BOAKYEM, (SUB. BY ERIC O. BAIDOO)
summary: This Court of Appeal judgment from Ghana, delivered on June 18, 2002, concerns a land dispute over approximately 70.91 acres at Senchi in the Eastern Region. The plaintiff, Seth Asante, claimed title based on a 1950 purchase by his late father, Kwame Amoaforo, from Isaac Mensavi Dugbatey, later evidenced in writing in 1960 with consent from the Omanhene of Akwamu Traditional Area. The plaintiff further claimed that the land was gifted to him and his siblings by his father’s customary successor, Kwaku Osei. The High Court had granted the plaintiff a declaration of title, damages for trespass, and a perpetual injunction. On appeal, the Court of Appeal allowed the appeal, holding that the plaintiff lacked capacity to sue because the alleged gift of land by the customary successor was invalid under Akan customary law. The court emphasized that upon the intestate death of Amoaforo, the land became family property, and any gift required consent from the family head and elders, along with public 'aseda' (customary acceptance), which were absent. Additionally, the court found the judgment below against the weight of evidence, as the plaintiff failed to prove root of title through Dugbatey or call key witnesses, including stool authorities or boundary owners. The appeal was allowed, and the lower court’s judgment was set aside.
citations: Kwakye v Tuba and Others [1961] GLR (Part II) 535
rationaleHighlights: The plaintiff lacked capacity to sue because the customary successor could not validly gift family land without consent of the family head and elders.
A gift of land under Akan customary law requires public 'aseda' and family approval, which were absent.
The judgment was against the weight of evidence as the plaintiff failed to prove root of title through Dugbatey.
No witness from the Amoaforo family or stool authorities was called to confirm the gift.
The land, if acquired by Amoaforo, became family property upon his intestate death, not personal property to be disposed of unilaterally.
The plaintiff failed to call boundary owners or Dugbatey’s vendors, weakening his evidential burden.
The trial court erred in treating the gift as valid without scrutiny of customary law requirements.
The appeal was allowed primarily due to failure to meet customary law standards for inter vivos gifts of land.
